_exec_summary.SummaryText:
HRONIS, INC.
COLD STORAGE FACILITY 
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Hronis, Inc. cold storage facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in two separate refrigeration systems at their cold storage facility located east of Delano, California.  The cold storage facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the applicable Uniform Building and Uniform Mechanical Codes.  

Additionally, Hronis, Inc. has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for the refrigeration systems.  As part of the PSM program, Hronis, Inc. completed process hazard analyses.  Hronis, Inc. utilizes contractors to implement a preventative maintenance program and mechanical integrity program to ensure that the refrigeration equipment is maintained in good operating condition.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an accidental release.

Personnel from Hronis, Inc. monitor the daily operation of the refrigeration systems.  All service, maintenance, and repairs to the ammonia refrigeration systems are contracted to a qualified and licensed refrigeration contractor specializing in ammonia refrigeration.  Utilizing an experienced qualified contractor to perform routine service, maintenance, and repairs ensures that the equipment is in excellent operating condition. 

While it is Hronis, Inc.?s objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the cold storage facility precludes emergency response operations.  As such, an emergency action plan has been prepared for the Hronis, Inc. cold storage facility and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.

Hronis, Inc. has developed a detailed Compliance Audit Checklist which is used to evaluate compliance with the Process Safety Management (PSM) and CalARP regulations.  At least every three years, Hronis, Inc. audits these programs and any f

indings of noncompliance are documented and responded to and the deficiencies are corrected.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 

Hronis, Inc. owns and operates a cold storage facility physically located at 10443 Hronis Road.  Delano is the closest city to the Hronis, Inc. cold storage facility.  The rural plant was originally constructed during 1980 utilizing all new equipment at the time of construction.  Several expansions to the refrigeration system have been completed with the latest expansion completed in 2005.  Figure 3.1 shows the location of the facility. 

Refrigeration System #1 consists of a suction accumulator with a liquid transfer system, five compressors, two evaporative condensers, a high pressure receiver, 6 pre-cool rooms, 7 cold storage rooms, and the associated hallway/loadout dock areas.  Refrigeration System #2 has a suction accumulator with a liquid transfer system, two compressors, one evaporative condenser, a high pressure receiver, 2 cold storage rooms, and the associated hallway/loadout dock areas.  Volume I, Section II of the PSM Supporting Document describes the ammonia refrigeration processes in detail.     

During normal operation, the anhydrous ammonia is distributed throughout the refrigeration systems.  However, during major maintenance activities, an entire refrigeration system can be ?pumped down? to evacuate the ammonia from the system and store it in the high pressure receiver.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the high pressure receiver in Refrigeration System #1 is 19,428 pounds.  In Refrigeration System #2, the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in the high pressure receiver is 12,723 pounds (although current ammonia charge is approximately 7800 pounds).

The characteristics and hazards of anhydrous ammonia are discussed briefly in Section 6.0 of this document and more extensively in Volume I, Section II of the PSM Supporting Document.  For purposes of the offsite

consequence analyses, 40 CFR Part 68 and the CalARP regulations define the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, has been implemented by Hronis, Inc. to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:

?    Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.

?    Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) have been completed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.

?    Written operating procedures will be reviewed at least annually.

?    Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility are implemented as needed.

?    If employees are involved in operating the ammonia system, they will receive initial training and refresher training at least every three years.

?    Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.

?    A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.

?    Pre-startup safety reviews will be performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

?    Audits will be conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the CalARP regulations.

?    Incident investigation procedures have been established.

?    A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.

?    Hot work permits will be issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system, as needed.

?    A Contractor Safety Policy has been

developed and implemented.

To ensure that the general accidental release prevention program and the chemical-specific prevention steps are implemented, Hronis, Inc. has assigned overall responsibility for the RMP elements to a partner in the firm.  The Partner has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements.

Five-Year Accident History
